_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Abstract

The EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulation applies to the TOTAL Petrochemicals & Refining USA, Inc - Bayport HDPE Plant (TOTAL Bayport) because of the quantities of titanium tetrachloride, butene, isobutane, and ethylene we safely handle in the production of high density polyethylene (HDPE).  Long standing safety systems have enabled us to successfully manage the risks associated with these, and other potentially dangerous materials, with zero incidents resulting in any impact to the community or the environment .



Background

TOTAL Bayport is located in the Bayport Industrial District in Pasadena, TX.  TOTAL has owned and operated the facility since purchasing the HDPE Plant in 1992.  The facility currently provides jobs for 110 fulltime TOTAL employees and approximately 50 fulltime contract employees.  The facility consists of two HDPE production units, Bay 1 and Bay 2.  TOTAL Bayport has maintained an outstanding environmental and safety record through a commitment to operating our plant in a manner which is safe for our people and for our community.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

We are committed to conducting our activities with the highest regard for environmental, health, safety, and community well-being. Safety is integrated into all activities of all employees working at the TOTAL Bayport plant.  As a member of the American Chemistry Council (ACC), TOTAL Bayport is committed to the principles of Responsible Care©.  Commitment to safety and the environment comes from top management, both on site and corporate.  This is demonstrated by both our site operating philosophy and our corporate "Health, Safety, Security, Environment, Quality Charter" described below.



"We shall conduct our operations in a manner that protects the safety and health of our employees, contractors and the public as well as the quality of the environment. This HSSEQ Policy is founded upon the values set forth in Responsible Care®

and its Guiding Principles as well as the Total Group HSEQ Charter, Total Refining & Chemicals Health Safety and Environment Policy, and Total Group Security Charter. No economic priority shall overrule these principles . In support of this policy, we will:

? Design and operate our facilities to ensure operational safety, optimize resource conservation, reduce waste and emissions and minimize adverse impact on health and the environment.

? Comply with applicable laws, regulations, codes and standards, and provide monitoring to ensure compliance.

? Seek continual improvement in health, safety, security, environmental and quality performance with a vision to eliminate accidents and incidents.

? Protect employees, assets, information and corporate reputation by maintaining comprehensive security systems.

? Establish effective HSSEQ management systems that include promoting practices beyond regulatory compliance, routine evaluation of system performance and a framework for setting HSSEQ goals, objectives and targets.

? Integrate the principles of sustainable development into our decision-making.

? Choose suppliers, partners, and contractors that share and adhere to our principles .

? Produce, market and distribute only those products that, when properly used, will not pose an unacceptable risk to health and the environment while practicing effective product stewardship.

? Communicate to employees, contractors, customers, and the public any known hazards of our products and operations.

? Encourage listening, mutual support, and the sharing and communication of good practices while promoting transparency among stakeholders.

? Support and encourage innovative technology and research programs that promote good science and seek reasonable solutions to HSSEQ challenges.

? Review and test emergency procedures to ensure a prompt and effective response.



The management of each Local Business Unit and Business Unit is responsible for implementation of this Policy,

and all employees and contractors have a personal responsibility to adhere to these principles. HSSEQ performance shall be an important element in the evaluation of employees and contractors."



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The EPA RMP regulation applies to TOTAL Bayport because of the quantities of titanium tetrachloride, butene, isobutane, and ethylene we safely handle in the production of high density polyethylene (HDPE).  Titanium tetrachloride is on the list of EPA toxic RMP materials and is used in the manufacturing of the catalyst used in our Bay 1 process.  Butene, isobutane, and ethylene are on the RMP flammables list.  Butene is added to the HDPE polymer as a comonomer to control density.  Isobutane is used as a solvent in the Bay 2 process.  Ethylene is used as the feedstock in both the Bay 1 and Bay 2 processes.  



Accidental Release Prevention Program

TOTAL has put a program in place to meet or exceed every requirement of the accidental release prevention provisions set forth in 40 CFR Part 68 by the EPA.  The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with applicable standards and industry best practices.  Processes at our facility are subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.    The following sections briefly describe the main elements of the accidental release prevention program that are in place at our facility. 



1. Employee Participation - all employees at TOTAL Bayport are involved in our safety program.  TOTAL believes that process safety management and accident prevention are a team effort.  Company employees actively participate in accident prevention and development of our process safety management programs.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the Risk Management Plan rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses.



2. Proces

s Safety Information (PSI) - TOTAL maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with our processes.  The information is kept current and is available to all employees.



3. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) - Systems are in place to safely manage change as part of our process safety management program.   Comprehensive hazard reviews (where teams of employees examine potential hazards and develop ways to mitigate them) are performed to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled effectively.  The reviews are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at regular intervals.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed promptly.  



4. Operating Procedures - In order to safely conduct activities at our facility, TOTAL maintains detailed written operating procedures.  These procedures cover initial plant startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  They describe the tasks we must perform, safe operating parameters that we must maintain, and safety precautions for operations and maintenance activities.  The procedures are reviewed regularly and are readily accessible to our Operators. 



5. Training - TOTAL has a formal training program to ensure that all employees who are operating processes are trained and tested in the operating procedures associated with these processes.   Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.  During the training, each employee must demonstrate that they have the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties and responsibilities as provided in our operating procedures. 



6. Contractors - Our company hires contractors to perform maintenance and construction acti

vities at the facility.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out.  TOTAL has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and our processes.  Contractors are also informed of all of the emergency response procedures should an accidental release occur.  



7. Pre-Startup Safety Review - Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at TOTAL.  These reviews are used to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup before ever placing equipment into operation.



8. Mechanical Integrity - We have comprehensive preventive maintenance and mechanical integrity programs in place for the entire facility.  The program incorporates industry codes, procedures from federal and state regulations, and instructions provided by equipment manufacturers.  TOTAL carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



9. Management of Change - Written procedures are used at TOTAL to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, and other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and provided training on any modification.



10. Incident Investigation - TOTAL promptly investigates any incident or near miss that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release or injury.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions necessary to prevent a

release or injury from reoccurring.  Investigation report findings are shared with all employees affected by the findings.  



Five-Year Accident History

TOTAL has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last five years.  Due to our stringent prevention policies, there have been no releases of any RMP regulated chemicals at our facility that have had any impact on the community, the environment, or plant personnel.



Emergency Response Program

TOTAL has a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of regulatory agencies and the public, on and offsite monitoring, as well as post-incident clean up of any affected areas.  The emergency response plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.  We coordinate our emergency plan with the Southeast Regional LEPC, our facility's Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  TOTAL Bayport has been an active member of the LEPC since purchasing the plant in 1992.  The planning effort of the LEPC helps ensure our emergency plan is coordinated with that of the local municipalities.  



To quickly and effectively respond to emergencies at our facility, TOTAL maintains both a mobile aerial foam truck and a fast attack truck onsite.  The entire plant is surrounded by an underground firewater header that will supply firewater from our 1.2 million gallon firewater storage tank.  In addition, our firewater system is also tied into the fire water system of the neighboring plant. This serves both as a backup to our system and offers additional firewater capacity if needed.  Fixed fire monitors and deluge systems are in place throughout the facility to respond to fires.  We have emergency flares in place to safely combust flammable chemicals during up

sets or emergencies.  To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. 



The facility has a alarm system to alert nearby persons during emergencies.  We also have procedures in place to alert the surrounding communities during emergencies. 

We employ trained emergency responders, including onsite industrial firefighters, who train annually at the Texas A&M University Industrial Fire Fighting School.  We also have an onsite emergency medical team and an onsite rescue team.  Our hazardous materials response team is HAZMAT certified and can respond to incidents both on and offsite.  Additional personnel are on contract to provide emergency response equipment, expertise, and manpower if needed.  



We have an emergency communications link to offsite responders through our emergency radio system, which we and our neighboring plants continuously monitor.  In addition to the Southeast Regional LEPC, we also closely coordinate our emergency plan with Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA).  Procedures are in place to quickly notify CIMA by radio or telephone to bring in additional help if required.  CIMA is the largest industry mutual aid organization in the world.  It is a joining together of firefighting, rescue, hazardous materials, and emergency medical manpower and equipment from more than 100 industrial facilities and federal, state, and local emergency response agencies in the Houston area for mutual assistance in case of an emergency.  Our responders participate in the annual CIMA Zone 4 Drill and the annual general membership drill.



Continual Improvement

Continual improvement is an integral component of our risk management program.  We recognize that even the best system can be improved.  We are continually working to reduce our accident and release rate, primarily through employee involvement in our Facility Safety Plan.  We seek to learn as much as possible from facility drills and any unusual incidents.  S

everal developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program.  We installed emergency shutdown and isolation systems for the unloading of railcars and tank trucks containing flammable products.   We have added cameras to view unloading operations and have the ability to remotely shut down the unloading process.  We also added additional deluge systems and improved our facility foam systems.  Revalidation of our Process Hazard Analysis, Operator Requalification, and continued development of the Advanced Integrated Management System (AIMS) are other major steps we have taken to further improve safety at our facility.
